questions.text: A 42-year-old asymptomatic woman is diagnosed with COVID 19 infection. Her CT chest is unremarkable. She was incidentally diagnosed with gall stones 2 months back and wishes to get an elective surgery done. As per the American Society of Anesthesiologists, how long is the suggested wait time for elective surgeries after diagnosis of COVID 19?
questions.solution:
For asymptomatic and mildly symptomatic COVID 19 positive patients, elective surgeries can be planned 4 weeks from the date of diagnosis of COVID-19.

The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) recommended waiting time for elective surgery from the date of diagnosis of COVID-19 infection are as follows:  

  • 4 weeks for an asymptomatic patient or recovery from only mild, non-respiratory symptoms
  • 6 weeks for symptomatic patients with cough/dyspnea not requiring hospitalization
  • 8 to 10 weeks for symptomatic patients who required hospitalization and/or diabetic patients and/or immunocompromised
  • 12 weeks for patients that had to be admitted to the ICU due to COVID 19  

The American College of Surgeons recommends non-operative management, if feasible and safe for the patient in surgical emergencies in a COVID-19 positive patient or is at high clinical suspicion of COVID-19.

If the surgery is required in such patients, then proper personal protective equipment should be utilized and precautions to be taken to protect the health care team.

questions.text: A 16-year-old, healthy otherwise asymptomatic girl, who wanted to join back in her school after lockdown came to the local PHC for taking the rapid antigen test for COVID-19. She has tested positive. Which of the following is the next best appropriate step?

choices.text: Repeat an RT-PCR test for her
Admit her to the COVID unit

questions.solution:
The given scenario is an asymptomatic mild case of COVID-19 with no risk factors who can be recommended home isolation for a duration of 10 days starting from symptom onset. Repeating the RAT test is not recommended. A single Positive RAT is sufficient enough to make the diagnosis of COVID19.

Isolation is the separation and restriction of movements or activities of persons who are sick, to prevent the transmission of disease. Eligibility for home isolation:

  • The person should be clinically assigned as a mild case or asymptomatic case by the treating medical officer.
  • Such cases should have the requisite facility at their residence for self-isolation and also for quarantining the family contacts.
  • The caregiver should be available and a communication link between the caregiver and the hospital should be established.
  • The patient must monitor his health regularly and inform his health status to the district surveillance officer.

The patient can end home isolation after 10 days of onset of symptoms (or date of sampling for pre-symptomatic cases) and no fever for 3 days. There is no need for testing after the home isolation period is over.

The patient should seek medical help if he develops:

  • Difficulty in breathing
  • Persistent pain/pressure in the chest
  • Mental confusion or inability to arouse
  • Dip in oxygen saturation (SpO2 < 94% on room air)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about COVID 19?
  1. It is caused by an enveloped RNA virus with club-shaped spikes
  2. Biosafety level 2 is the minimum required for the culture of this virus
  3. FELUDA based on CRISPR gene-editing technology is a strip test that could detect the SARS COV-2 genes
  4. KAVACH ELISA is used for antigen detection
  5. SARS COV 2 belongs to the family called Orthomyxoviridae
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 3 are true about COVID-19. SARS - COV2 is an enveloped RNA virus with club-shaped spikes and FELUDA based on the CRISPR gene-editing technology is a strip test that can detect SARS COV 2 genes.

A biosafety level cabinet BSL of level 3 is required for culturing the virus while a level 2 would suffice for specimen handling or molecular testing of the virus. KAVACH ELISA is for antibody detection of COVID-19. Coronavirus belongs to the family of Coronaviridae.

Coronaviruses are enveloped positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses with an unsegmented genome, and they exhibit helical symmetry. 

The coronaviridiae have a single unsegmented ss (+) RNA which is, in fact, the largest genome among RNA viruses. They are about 120 - 160 nm in size and contain a helical nucleocapsid. It also has spike proteins - S1 and S2. They are responsible for the host specificty, faster spread of the disease and it is highly suscpetible to mutations. While S1 protein is involved in the attachment of the virus with ACE-2 receptor, S2 protein is involved in virus-host cell fusion. 

The virus responsible for the recent pandemic that started in 2019 is named SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome- coronavirus-2) and the disease it causes has been named coronavirus disease 2019 (abbreviated COVID-19). 

SARS-CoV-2 is a member of the order Nidovirales, family Coronaviridae, subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, genera Betacoronavirus, and sub-genus Sarbecovirus.

questions.text:
In which of the following patients, would you administer Covidshield vaccination?
  1. A 51-year-old man who underwent hematopoietic stem cell transplantation 5 weeks ago for aplastic anemia. 
  2. A 60-year-old man with a history of type-2 diabetes mellitus. 
  3. A 32-year-old woman who received TT immunization 20 days back following a trivial fall from a bike.
  4. A 45-year-old man on dialysis three times a week for chronic kidney disease.
  5. A 40-year-old woman on insulin therapy for type-1 diabetes mellitus.
questions.solution:
The 51-year-old man should receive COVID-19 vaccination at least 3 months after hematopoietic cell transplantation (and not 5 weeks) to maximize vaccine efficacy. 

Graft-versus-host disease and immunosuppressive regimens like systemic corticosteroids can blunt the immune responses to vaccination. Delay of vaccination until immunosuppressive therapy is reduced can be considered. 

Consider additional risk factors linked to adverse COVID-19 complications including, but not limited to: 

  • Patients with advanced age (eg, ≥65 years of age) 
  • Patients with comorbidities (eg, chronic pulmonary, cardiovascular, or renal disease) 
  • Social and demographic factors

COVID-19 vaccines should be prioritized over other vaccines. A gap of 14 days is recommended between COVID-19 vaccines and any other vaccine. 

If COVID vaccine has been given first, then TT vaccine can be given on the same day. If TT vaccine have been given first, then wait for 14 days to give COVID vaccine.

questions.text: The following equipment with a sample was sent from the COVID-19 positive ward for testing. Where should the empty container be disposed of?
questions.solution:
The image shows an Eppendorf micro-centrifugation tube. It should be discarded in red bin.

These are single-use disposable tubes used for storing human test samples (except blood) for in-vitro testing. The tube is sensitive to temperature and seals may breach in higher temperatures.

questions.text:
A young girl, who recently recovered from COVID-19, presents with fever, abdominal pain and rashes for 4 days. On examination, strawberry tongue is observed and cervical nodes are found to be enlarged bilaterally. What is the likely diagnosis?

HR: 110/min

BP: 80/60 mm Hg

RR: 20/min

CRP: 10 mg/L

ESR: 76mm/hr.
questions.solution:
This is a case of multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C), associated with COVID-19 infection.

Diagnostic criteria for MIS-C:

Children and adolescents 0–18 years of age with fever ≥3 days

AND two of these:

  • Rash or bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis or mucocutaneous inflammation signs (palmoplantar erythema, lip hyperemia, periorbital erythema and edema, strawberry tongue, and malar erythema)
  • Hypotension or shock.
  • Features of myocardial dysfunction, pericarditis, valvulitis, or coronary abnormalities (including ECHO findings or elevated Troponin/NT-proBNP)
  • Evidence of coagulopathy (PT, PTT, elevated D-Dimers)
  • Acute gastrointestinal problems (diarrhoea, vomiting, or abdominal pain)

AND

Elevated ESR(>40 mm), C-reactive protein (>5 mg/L), or procalcitonin.

AND

No other obvious microbial cause of inflammation including bacterial sepsis, staphylococcal or streptococcal shock syndromes.

AND

Evidence of COVID-19 (RT-PCR, antigen test, or serology positive), or likely contact with patients with COVID-19.

Types of MIS-C:

  • MIS-C with shock/multi-organ dysfunction
  • Kawasaki phenotype
  • MIS-C without shock

MIS-C is treated with IV methylprednisolone. The dose can be increased in patients with shock. If the condition does not improve for 48-72 hours, specialists can be consulted for the addition of biologicals to the treatment regimen.

questions.text:
A G2P1 woman presents to the clinic at 37 weeks of gestation with mild dyspnea. Her husband was COVID positive and now she has tested positive for COVID 19. She is febrile and you note that she is tachypneic on examination. Which of the following is/are incorrect regarding the management of this patient?
  1. She needs admission to a tertiary care center.
  2. Maternal heart rate, respiratory rate BP, and temperature should be measured at least 3-4 times a day
  3. Fetal heart rate should be measured once in 2 days
  4. Betamethasone injection should not be given as it can worsen COVID in the mother
  5. Once delivered, RT-PCR of the New-born should be done
questions.solution:
As the pregnant female has tested positive for SARS COV 2 she requires admission to a tertiary care center. Once admitted, maternal surveillance should include maternal heart rate, respiratory rate BP, and temperature measurement at least 3-4 times a day along with requisite chest imaging using X-ray or CT.

As part of fetal monitoring, FHR should be measured on a daily basis, not once in two days. Since the patient is at 37 weeks, betamethasone should be given to facilitate fetal maturation. Betamethasone can be given to mothers between 34-37 weeks. IV antibiotics can be added as per the local protocols.

Once delivered, RT-PCR of the New-born should be done.

questions.text: Working as a duty doctor in a COVID care centre, you were trained on sanitation techniques, donning, doffing of PPE and other preventive measures to reduce the incidence of disease. You were recommended to use alcohol-based hand rubs to curtail the spread of COVID-19 infection. The microbiological basis for the same would be?

choices.text: COVID-19 virus has a lipid envelope
COVID-19 virus has a glycoprotein capsid

questions.solution:
Alcohol-based hand rubs are preferred because COVID 19 virus has a lipid envelope that contributes to its susceptibility to lipid solvents. 

Coronaviruses are enveloped helically symmetrical viruses. Alcohol, especially ethanol present in the hand rubs, dissolves the lipid envelope and denatures the proteins present. This leads to membrane disruption and inhibition of the metabolism, as depicted below:

The Coronaviridiae have a single unsegmented ss (+) RNA which is, in fact, the largest genome among RNA viruses. They are about 120 - 160 nm in size and contain a helical nucleocapsid. They have club-shaped or petal-shaped projections that are widely spaced on the outer surface of the envelope, suggestive of a solar corona.

The virus has spike proteins - S1 and S2 which are responsible for the host specificity, faster spread of the disease, and make it highly susceptible to mutations. While S1 protein is involved in the attachment of the virus with the ACE-2 receptor, S2 protein is involved in virus-host cell fusion. 

The virus responsible for the pandemic that started in 2019 is named SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome- coronavirus-2) and the disease it causes has been named coronavirus disease 2019 (abbreviated COVID-19). 

SARS-CoV-2 is a member of the order Nidovirales, family Coronaviridae, subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, and is considered to be a new member of the genus Betacoronavirus.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female diagnosed with mild-moderate COVID19 gave birth to a healthy, term neonate. It was a spontaneous vaginal delivery at 38 weeks of gestation with uneventful intrapartum history. The APGAR score of the baby at 1 and 5 minutes were 8/10 and 9/10 respectively. You are the rotating intern from the department of pediatrics. Which of the following would you be correct to advise?
  1. Colocation should be avoided if possible.
  2. If the mother is not willing to stay separated, you can arrange for a screen between the two. 
  3. A dedicated breast pump must not be provided to the mother. The breast pump in the ward can be used as usual.
  4. In case she does not have a caregiver, you can ask the mother to feed the baby herself wearing a face mask and after performing hand hygiene.
  5. The newborn should be kept ≥6 feet away from the ill mother.
questions.solution:
The correct advice would include 1, 2, 4, and 5.

Guidelines for Neonatal management of a baby born to COVID19 positive mother include:

  1. Mother and child should be separated from each other.
  2. Colocation / Rooming-in should be avoided as and when possible.
  3. If the situation demands rooming-in or if the mother does not have a healthy caregiver or if she is not consenting to the separation, arrangements have to be made accordingly. A screen can be placed in between the two and a distance of 6 feet minimum can be maintained between the two. 
  4. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in COVID19 infected mothers. 
  5. Mother can express the breastmilk using a dedicated breast pump and ask the caregiver to feed the child. If a dedicated breast pump is not available, all parts
    that come into contact with breast milk should be thoroughly washed and the entire pump should be appropriately disinfected as per the manufacturer’s instructions after each pumping session.
  6. In case the caregiver is not available, she can feed the child directly wearing a face mask and she must follow hand hygiene properly.

questions.text: A 48-year-old CKD patient had tested positive for COVID-19 infection. He was also put on a ventilator due to worsening saturation but, unfortunately, he passed away. A pathologist working in your hospital is researching histopathology of COVID19 infection and takes a section of the diseased lung. She notices the image shown below under her microscope. Which of the following is wrong about the given finding?

choices.text: The image shows diffuse alveolar damage
It is specific to COVID 19 pneumonia
This is the commonest pattern of lung lesions in patients with COVID-19
Commonly associated with mononuclear cell infiltration

questions.solution:
The given HP slide shows Diffuse alveolar damage and it is non-specific to COVID 19 pneumonia.

Though diffuse alveolar damage is the most common finding in the histopathological analysis of COVID-19 infected lungs, it is not specific to COVID-19. It can also be seen in ARDS, burns, near-drowning. 

Other findings seen in the lungs infected with COVID-19 include:

  • Hyaline membrane formation
  • Desquamation of pneumocytes
  • Fibrin deposits in the lungs
  • Inflammation with mononuclear cells

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in casualty. An elderly 60-year-old man is brought to you with complaints of chest pain. He has tested positive for COVID. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to dedicated COVID Health Centre?

A. Respiratory rate of 25/min
B. SpO2 93%
C. Multiple comorbidities
D. Chest pain
E. Age
questions.solution: A, B, C & E are clinical criteria of admission under COVID-19 ward.

questions.text:
Which case scenarios along with the drugs prescribed are inappropriate?
  1. A man on anti-retroviral therapy with severe COVID pneumonia- Tocilizumab
  2. A non-hospitalized middle-aged diabetic man with mild COVID pneumonia- Bamlanivimab
  3. A mother on post-partum day 3 with moderate COVID pneumonia maintaining with NIPPV- Remedisivir
  4. A woman with COVID-19 disease- Convalescent plasma therapy
  5. A woman with moderate COVID pneumonia on supplemental oxygen- Dexamethasone
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, and 4.

  1. Tocilizumab is contraindicated in HIV-positive patients and those with active bacterial or fungal infection.
  2. Bamlanivimab is not authorized for patients with mild COVID-19 pneumonia who are not at a high risk for hospitalization.
  3. Remedisivir is contraindicated in postnatal lactating women.
  4. Convalescent plasma therapy is no longer recommended in the management of COVID patients.

Tocilizumab acts by IL-6 inhibition. It may be considered in moderate-severe COVID patients with progressively increasing oxygen requirements and mechanically ventilated patients not improving despite the use of steroids. Patients should be carefully monitored for secondary infections and neutropenia after treatment with tocilizumab. It is contraindicated in:

  • HIV 
  • Active infections (systemic bacterial/fungal)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Active hepatitis
  • Absolute neutrophil count < 2000/mm3
  • Platelet count < 1,00,000/mm3

Bamlanivimab is a monoclonal antibody directed against the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2. The FDA has issued an emergency use authorization for bamlanivimab for the treatment of adult and pediatric mild to moderate COVID patients (12 years of age and older weighing at least 40 kilograms) who are at high risk for progressing to severe COVID-19 and/or hospitalization. Possible side effects include anaphylaxis and infusion-related reactions, nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache, itching, and vomiting. There is no specific contraindication for this drug. 

Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that works by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. It may be considered in moderate and severe hospitalized COVID patients requiring supplemental oxygen/oxygen delivery through a high flow device/ noninvasive ventilation/ invasive mechanical ventilation/ ECMO. It is contraindicated in: 

  • AST/ALT > 5 times upper limit of normal
  • Severe renal impairment (i.e., eGFR < 30ml/min/m2 or need for hemodialysis) 
  • Pregnancy or lactating females 
  • Children <12 years of age

Convalescent plasma therapy is no longer recommended in the management of COVID patients, as per the revised guidelines.

Dexamethasone is generally given to all patients of moderate and severe COVID-19. Patients with severe COVID-19 can develop a systemic inflammatory response that can lead to lung injury and multisystem organ dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following is a criterion for discharge in a patient with mild COVID-19 infection?

choices.text: Discharge after 10 days from testing positive & no fever for 3 days
Discharge after 7 days from testing positive & no fever for 3 days
Discharge if SpO2>98% on room air for 3 consecutive days
Discharge if repeat RT-PCR testing is negative

questions.solution:
COVID-19 cases that are mild/very mild/presymptomatic can be discharged from home isolation after 7 days of testing positive and no fever for 3 successive days. There is no need for testing after the end of home isolation. 

Criteria to diagnose asymptomatic COVID-19: Laboratory confirmed case with no symptoms with a saturation of more than 93% in room air. 

Criteria to diagnose mild COVID-19: Laboratory confirmed case with upper respiratory tract symptoms with/without fever, without shortness of breath, and saturation of more than 93% in room air. 

Patients are advised to isolate from other family members and monitor themselves at home, under proper medical guidance. Patients >60 years with co-morbidities, and immunocompromised patients are allowed to isolate only after receiving clearance from the designated medical officer. 

Immediate medical attention is required if the patient experiences the following: 

  • A 100 ºF fever persists for >3 days and does not resolve on medication.
  • Difficulty in breathing 
  • Oxygen saturation ≤93% (at least 3 readings within 1 hour)
  • Respiratory rate >24/min
  • Persistent chest pain or pressure
  • Mental confusion 
  • Severe fatigue or myalgia

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, known case of diabetes mellitus type-2, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease, presents to the ER with complaints of breathing difficulty and fever. On examination, pulse rate is 96 bpm, BP is 118/70 mmHg, the temperature is 100.4 degree F, RR is 15/min and SpO2 is 96%. RT PCR indicates he is COVID positive. Chest CT as shown below demonstrates ground-glass opacities close to the visceral pleural surfaces and visible intralobular lines. Which CO-RADS (COVID-19 Reporting and Data System) category does this patient fall under?
questions.solution:
As the patient has a positive COVID RT PCR, he would be classified as CORADS 6 - irrespective of his CT appearance.

 

CO-RADS Categories

CO-RADS 0 (Not interpretable - Technically insufficient to assign a score): Scans are incomplete or of inferior quality.

CO-RADS 1 (Very low risk - Normal/Non-infectious): Very low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Mild or severe emphysema, perifissural nodules, lung tumors, or fibrosis.

CO-RADS 2 (Low - Typical for other infections but not COVID-19): Low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Includes infectious etiology that is not compatible with COVID-19 such as bronchitis, bronchiolitis, bronchopneumonia, lobar pneumonia, abscess.

CO-RADS 3 (Equivocal - Features compatible with COVID-19, but also other diseases): Equivocal findings for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Findings overlap with other viral or infectious etiologies. Could include perihilar ground-glass, homogenous extensive ground-glass with or without sparing of secondary pulmonary lobules.

CO-RADS 4 (High - Suspicious for COVID-19): High level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Findings are similar to CO-RADS 5 but are not present in the typical locations. Findings may also be superimposed on severe pre-existing pulmonary abnormalities.

CO-RADS 5 (very high level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19) based on typical CT findings. It requires the presence of at least one confirmatory pattern - which includes ground glass regions, crazy paving pattern, and/or organizing pneumonia compatible patterns. Thickened vessels with parenchymal abnormalities is found in all confirmatory patterns

CO-RADS 6 (Proven): Proven COVID-19 by positive RT-PCR test.

questions.text: The median incubation period of the SARS-COV2 virus is?
questions.solution:
The median incubation period is around 4-6 days. The incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 infection ranges from 2-14 days.

The incubation period is the time interval between invasion of the infectious agent and appearance of the first symptom or sign in the body. It is termed as the latent period in non-infectious diseases. The incubation period depends upon generation time of the pathogen, the portal of entry, infective dose, and individual susceptibility.

The median incubation period is the time required for 50% of the cases to occur after exposure. 

Application of incubation period is for

  • Tracing the source of infection and contacts
  • Determining the period of surveillance or quarantine
  • For immunization
  • Identification of point source or propagated epidemics
  • Prognosis

Quarantine is the limitation in freedom of movement of healthy contacts of cases, who have been exposed for a period that lasts as much as the maximal incubation period of the disease. It is a primary level of prevention, under specific protection. That is why contacts of COVID 19 patients are quarantined for 14 days.

questions.text: A thirteen-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and cough. His history is significant for frequent fever and painful swelling of hands after playing football. His mother brings an old sonology report which reveals his spleen to be shrunken. His vitals are within normal limits. You order certain radiological investigations and RT-PCR tests for SARS-COV2 and he is diagnosed with mild to moderate COVID. His vitals are stable and hence you decide to treat him on an outpatient basis. You can use all of the following drugs, as part of a combination, to treat the coronavirus disease in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The finding of dactylitis along with the shrunken spleen is suggestive of sickle cell disease.

Crizanlizumab is a selectin blocker indicated to reduce the frequency of vasoocclusive crises in adults and pediatric patients aged 16 years and older with sickle cell disease. It is not used to treat COVID.

The FDA has given emergency use authorization for the use of the following combination anti-SARS-CoV-2 monoclonal antibodies to treat outpatients with mild to moderate COVID-19 who are at high risk of clinical progression:

  • Bamlanivimab 700 mg plus etesevimab 1,400 mg administered together
  • Casirivimab 1,200 mg plus imdevimab 1,200 mg administered together

Bamlanivimab and etesevimab are neutralizing IgG1 monoclonal antibodies that bind to distinct but overlapping epitopes within the receptor-binding domain of the spike protein of SARS-CoV2. 

Casirivimab and imdevimab are also IgG1 monoclonal antibodies that bind to non-overlapping epitopes of the spike protein receptor-binding domain (RBD) of SARS-CoV-2 and block the RBD binding to the human ACE2 receptor. The FDA has issued an emergency use authorization for using this combination for the treatment of adult and pediatric mild to moderate COVID patients (12 years of age and older weighing at least 40 kilograms) who are at high risk for progressing to severe COVID-19 and/or hospitalization.

Indication:

High-Risk Criteria for Emergency Use Authorization

High-risk individuals who at least one of the following criteria:

  • BMI ≥35
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Diabetes mellitusImmunocompromising condition
  • Currently receiving immunosuppressive treatment
  • Aged ≥65 years
  • Aged ≥55 years and have Cardiovascular disease; or Hypertension; or Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease/other chronic respiratory diseases.

For those between 12 - 17 years: (either of the following)

  • BMI ≥85th percentile for their age and gender-based on the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention growth charts
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Congenital or acquired heart disease
  •  Neurodevelopmental disorders, for example, cerebral palsy
  • A medical-related technological dependence, for example, tracheostomy, gastrostomy, or positive pressure ventilation (not related to COVID-19)
  • Asthma or a reactive airway or other chronic respiratory diseases that require daily medication
    for control.

The following parameters should raise the suspicion of COVID sepsis in a pediatric population: 

Hypotension ( SBP < 5th centile or > 2SD below normal for age)

OR

Presence of any two of the following:

  1. altered mental state
  2. Tachycardia / Bradycardia (HR <70 bpm or HR >150 bpm in children) (HR < 90 bpm or HR > 160bpm in infants )
  3. Prolonged capillary refill time >2sec
  4. warm vasodilation with bounding pulses
  5. Skin changes - mottling, petechiae rash, purpura
  6. increased lactate > 2mmol
  7. Oliguria
  8. Temperature changes - Hypo / Hyperthermia. 

Management:

  • Treat as severe COVID pneumonia
  • early recognition
  • vasopressors
  • antimicrobials within 1 hour
  • Avoid hypotonic crystalloids, gelatins for resuscitation.
  • Signs of poor perfusion / cardiac dysfunction - add inotropes - Dobutamine

Target:

  • Mean Arterial Pressure > 65mm of Hg.
  • urine output (>0.5ml/kg/hr in adults and >1ml/kg/hr in children
  • Improve skin mottling
  • capillary refill - WNL
  • Level of conciousness - normal 
  • Serum lactate levels - lowered 

In sickle cell disease, repeated splenic micro-infarcts cause loss of splenic function and shrinkage. Vaso-occlusion causes hand-foot syndrome with painful infarction of the digits and dactylitis.

Other manifestations include:

  • Acute splenic sequestration due to venous obstruction, necessitating emergency transfusion/splenectomy
  • Painful ischemic crises due to vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal tissue
  • Renal papillary necrosis leading to isosthenuria
  • Cerebrovascular strokes
  • Chronic lower leg ulcers
  • Priapism in males

NOTE:

FDA has recently expanded the emergency use authorization for the monoclonal antibody combination Bamlanivimab and Etesevimab. It can now be used for the treatment of mild to moderate COVID-19 and for post-exposure prophylaxis in all patients, including newborns who are at high risk for progression to severe COVID-19.

questions.text: A 45-year-old African-American presents to you with puffiness of the face, edema of feet, and oliguria. Past history was significant for COVID 19 disease. He was on home quarantine for 17 days. It has been a week since his quarantine period got over. The histopathological image of a section of his kidney is indicative of collapsing glomerulopathy and appears as shown below. Which of the following genes increases the risk of this disease entity in COVID-19 patients?
questions.solution:
Apolipoprotein L1 (APOL1) gene increases the risk of collapsing nephropathy in patients infected with COVID-19. The given HP section shows collapsing nephropathy with microcystic tubular dilatation and tubular injury.

This type of COVID-19-​associated nephropathy (COVAN) specifically affects individuals of African ancestry who are carriers of this gene variant. Histopathology is similar to those seen in other forms of collapsing glomerulopathy. But, tubulointerstitial lesions including microcystic tubular dilatation and tubular injury are typically associated with APOL1- related disease. 

 

The proposed pathogenesis of COVAN is as follows:

Pathogenesis involves activation of the interferon-chemokine pathway, which interacts with the APOL1 variant gene leading to tubuloreticular lesions and inclusions described as 'Interferon footprints'.

It is interesting to note that collapsing glomerulopathy was first characterized in individuals with HIV infection and became recognized as the classic histomorphological form of HIV-associated nephropathy (HIVAN).

Other causes of collapsing glomerulopathy:

  • HIV
  • SLE
  • Parvovirus B19
  • CMV
  • EBV
  • Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis
  • PLA-2R associated membranous nephropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be useful in a patient with severe COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Favipiravir (inhibits viral RNA polymerase) was the first oral drug approved in India for restricted emergency use for the treatment of mild to moderate COVID-19 patients. It was not approved for severe COVID-19. 

 

Note: This is a question from INICET 2020, during which time Favipiravir had gained approval from DCGI for mild to moderate COVID. The current clinical management protocol for COVID-19 does not recommend Favipiravir.

questions.text: The specimens collected for COVID-19 testing should be transported to the lab at what temperatures?
questions.solution:
Specimens collected for COVID-19 testing should be transported to the lab at a temperature of 2 to 8 degrees C as per the WHO guidelines. The ICMR/NIV guidelines recommend 4 degrees C for transport to the laboratory. 

Both guidelines recommend storing specimens at -70°C or below if a delay in testing or shipping is expected.
